Expectation1: Attending children's school events and activities
Situation1: The school reports that the child was caught bullying a classmate, and the parent needs to respond
Situation2: This is the last weekend before the partner relocates abroad for months.
Story: I stared at my phone, my heart pounding. The school had just called—my son was caught bullying a classmate, and they wanted me to come in for a meeting tomorrow morning. I felt a wave of disappointment and worry, knowing how important it was to be there for him, to show him that his actions had consequences and that I cared enough to help him make things right. But then I glanced at the suitcase by the door, a stark reminder that this was the last weekend before my boyfriend left for his new job overseas. We’d planned a special day together, just the two of us, to make memories before months apart. He’d been looking forward to it, and so had I. Now, I felt torn in two—my son needed me, but so did my partner. The weight of both expectations pressed down on me, and I could feel the anxiety rising as I tried to figure out how to be the parent my child needed and the girlfriend my partner deserved, all at the same time.
